content.description: Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia) is characterized by a marked, persistent fear or anxiety about one or more social situations where the individual may be scrutinized by others. The person fears acting in a way, or showing anxiety symptoms, that will be negatively evaluated (e.g., humiliation, embarrassment, rejection). These social situations almost always provoke fear/anxiety, are avoided or endured with intense distress, and cause significant functional impairment. Duration is typically ≥6 months.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Marked fear/anxiety about ≥1 social situations involving possible scrutiny. B. Fear of negative evaluation. C. Social situations almost always provoke fear/anxiety. D. Avoidance or endured with intense fear/anxiety. E. Disproportionate to actual threat. F. Persistent (≥6 months). G. Causes distress/impairment. H. Not attributable to a substance/medical condition. I. Not better explained by another mental disorder. J. If another medical condition is present, fear is unrelated or excessive.
content.prevalence: 12-month prevalence in U.S. adults ~7%; rates higher in females; often begins in adolescence.
content.age_of_onset: Median onset around age 13; may follow a humiliating social experience or emerge gradually.
content.prognosis: Chronic without treatment; early intervention improves long-term outcomes. Many develop comorbid depression or other anxiety disorders if untreated.

toddler_preschool: Extreme shyness or reluctance to interact with unfamiliar adults or peers.
Distress in group play or structured social activities.
childhood: Avoidance of speaking in class or participating in group activities.
Heightened worry before school events or performances.
adolescence: Significant distress about peer judgment, dating, or public speaking.
Withdrawal from extracurricular activities due to fear of embarrassment.
adulthood: Avoidance of career opportunities involving presentations or networking.
Social isolation or limited personal relationships due to persistent anxiety.

history_psychosocial: Situations feared or avoided, onset, and course of symptoms.
Impact on school/work, relationships, and daily life.
Family history of anxiety or mood disorders.
medical_assessment: Rule out conditions causing visible anxiety symptoms (e.g., hyperthyroidism, essential tremor).
differential_diagnosis: Panic Disorder, Agoraphobia, Generalized Anxiety Disorder

emotional_cognitive: Fear of embarrassment, humiliation, or rejection
physical: Racing heart or shortness of breath
behavioral: Avoidance of public speaking, meeting new people, eating in public
Limited eye contact, minimal verbal participation

severity_levels.mild: Anxiety in specific situations (e.g., public speaking) with minimal impairment in daily functioning.
severity_levels.moderate: Anxiety in multiple situations with avoidance and moderate functional impact.
severity_levels.severe: Anxiety in most social interactions, significant avoidance, marked impairment.

psychological: History of teasing, bullying, or humiliation
environmental: Cultural or situational emphasis on social performance

impact_on_life.school_work: Poor participation, avoidance of presentations, limited career advancement.
impact_on_life.emotional: Chronic feelings of loneliness, shame, or low self-esteem.

psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) — exposure therapy, cognitive restructuring, social skills training.
Group CBT for practicing skills in a safe setting.
medications: SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine, fluvoxamine) or SNRIs (venlafaxine XR) as first-line pharmacotherapy.
Benzodiazepines for short-term or situational use, with caution.
lifestyle_interventions: Gradual exposure to feared situations outside therapy.
Regular exercise and stress management strategies.

treatment_goals: Reduce fear and avoidance of social situations.
Increase participation and confidence in social/occupational settings.
Improve overall functioning and quality of life.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Misattributing symptoms to shyness without assessing impairment.
Overlooking in students with good academic performance but limited participation.
overdiagnosis_factors: Mislabeling performance-only anxiety as generalized SAD.
warning_signs: Persistent avoidance of social or performance situations despite consequences.
Marked distress in social interactions lasting ≥6 months.
Development of secondary depression or substance misuse.
self_help_strategies: Practice social skills in supportive environments.
Use graduated exposure to feared situations.
Challenge negative thoughts about social performance.
real_life_examples: A college student avoids speaking in class, leading to lower grades; CBT helps them participate confidently.
An employee turns down promotions requiring presentations; with therapy and gradual exposure, they accept a leadership role.
content.when_to_seek_help: When social fears persist ≥6 months, cause significant avoidance or distress, and interfere with school, work, or relationships.
